data.name: Insane Permutation Promenade (from AoC 2017 Day 16)
data.description:
# Problem Description

16 characters, named 'a' to 'p', are dancing in a line with some predefined steps.

There are three types of steps they may take:

* Spin, written `sX`, makes `X` characters move from the end to the front (i.e. rotate to right).
* Exchange, written `xA/B`, makes two characters at positions `A` and `B` swap places.
* Partner, written `pA/B`, makes two characters named `A` and `B` swap places.

Here are some examples with fewer characters:

```
Initial positions "abcde", Steps "s3,x1/2,pa/c"

abcde << initial positions
cdeab << after "s3" : spin 3
cedab << after "x1/2" : swap positions 1 and 2; positions are zero-indexed as usual
aedcb << after "pa/c" : swap characters a and c
```

The problem is that the characters are not dancing only once, but they dance indefinitely
repeating the given steps!
You must predict the positions of all characters after they dance `n` times with the given
steps `s`.

Some more examples:

```
Initial positions "abcde", Steps "s3,x1/2,pa/c", n = 2

aedcb << after first round finished
dcbae << after "s3" : spin 3
dbcae << after "x1/2" : swap positions 1 and 2; positions are zero-indexed as usual
dbace << after "pa/c" : swap characters a and c; two rounds finished
```

# Constraints

`1 <= (number of steps) <= 10,000`

`1 <= n <= 10 ** 9`

All inputs are valid. The format of `s` is strictly as above (comma-separated list, no whitespaces).

The initial positions are always a line of 16 characters `abc...p`.

If you have already solved this problem on AoC, you can freely reuse your code, and **I can almost guarantee it will fail** :P

# Examples

```python
permutation_promenade('s3', 1) == 'nopabcdefghijklm'
permutation_promenade('x1/2', 1) == 'acbdefghijklmnop'
permutation_promenade('pa/c', 1) == 'cbadefghijklmnop'

permutation_promenade('s3', 100) == 'efghijklmnopabcd'
permutation_promenade('x1/2,x1/3', 100) == 'adbcefghijklmnop'
permutation_promenade('pa/c,pc/f,pd/e', 100) == 'fbadecghijklmnop'
```

```javascript
permutationPromenade('s3', 1) == 'nopabcdefghijklm'
permutationPromenade('x1/2', 1) == 'acbdefghijklmnop'
permutationPromenade('pa/c', 1) == 'cbadefghijklmnop'

permutationPromenade('s3', 100) == 'efghijklmnopabcd'
permutationPromenade('x1/2,x1/3', 100) == 'adbcefghijklmnop'
permutationPromenade('pa/c,pc/f,pd/e', 100) == 'fbadecghijklmnop'
```

# Acknowledgement

This Kata was inspired by [Advent of Code 2017, Day 16](http://adventofcode.com/2017/day/16),
which is essentially the same task without time limit.
